title: Lessons for super funds from the man who hunted Madoff
text:
Either a genius or a fraud

DiBartolomeo was given limited information about the entity Markopolos called “Manager B”, a marketing document describing Madoff’s split/strike strategy and monthly performance numbers going back seven years.

Within a few hours, diBartolomeo knew the manager was either a genius, doing something illegal like front-running his clients, or a fraud. By the end of the day, he knew there was just a one in 200,000 chance Manager B was legitimate.

DiBartolomeo promptly forgot about the job, but Markopolos used Northfield’s numbers to appeal to the Securities and Exchange Commission to take action on Madoff.

Harry Markopolos came to Dan diBartolomeo to help expose Madoff. Bloomberg

DiBartolomeo says he finally learned who Manager B was at Christmas 2004, but it wasn’t until Madoff’s arrest in December 2008 that he connected the dots and became a minor celebrity for a few days.

He says he believes many of Madoff’s clients knew the manager was crooked but that they believed he was stealing for them, not from them.

While 95 per cent of Northfield’s revenue comes from selling risk management software and tools, the Madoff case was an example of what diBartolomeo describes as the weird problems clients bring him.

Advertisement

Like when the US pension giant California Public Employees' Retirement System asked Northfield to assess the risks and opportunities in hiring and firing its asset manager according to a formula, rather than by a specialist department. (It is possible, and delivers pretty similar results.)

Or when the US State Department asked diBartolomeo to examine whether sovereign wealth funds could protect their fixed income portfolios by using tools like charitable grants to forestall armed conflict. (If the sovereigns are big enough, this does indeed make sense).

Or when wealthy families want to understand how to diversify portfolios that include everything from global companies to rare art collections or jewellery. (You could actually get liquid proxy for an illiquid jewellery collection with a basket of gold, diamonds and Tiffany’s stock).

More going out than coming in

Or, as diBartolomeo discussed in Washington before travelling to Australia, when pension funds start to think about what happens when they have more money going out the door than coming in.

A potential problem in this shift, diBartolomeo says, comes from the increasing levels of illiquid assets in the portfolios of super funds. Pension funds have favoured things like infrastructure, private equity and property in recent years as they chase yield amid falling interest rates.

Selling liquid asset to pay benefits is relatively easy. But diBartolomeo argues pension funds need to consider the risk of being caught with a portfolio dominated with illiquid assets that are harder to liquidate.

This risk also needs to be considered in the context of an event like an equity market crash, where a pension fund might need to sell illiquid assets in a hurry, resulting in a value-destroying fire sale.

Advertisement

DiBartolomeo says an even greater danger stems from the fact that some pension funds have favoured illiquid assets because they aren’t subject to the daily price movements of equities or bonds. An office building, for example, would most likely be valued annually.

“The problem with that is that that tends to smooth out the ups and downs of the actual values by a great deal. You can greatly understate the risk in an illiquid asset,” diBartolomeo says.

But the value of illiquid assets does shift every day, even if that’s hard to track. While a commercial real estate firm might estimate price volatility in commercial property at, for example, 4 per cent across a year, diBartolomeo says this looks silly given listed property trusts, which collect a group of these assets, have annual volatility three times that.

Northfield’s aim is to use mathematical models to try to quantify risks like this and develop potential solutions.

In the case of illiquid assets, this could be a model to help a pension fund gradually sell down over a long period. Or it might involve developing the maths to show how a liquid substitute for illiquid assets – a basket of property trusts, construction companies and other stocks, for example – could work.

As diBartolomeo says, Northfield won’t tell a client what to believe. But the firm will give a client of a good sense of what the mathematics says they should do.

“A lot of what we do on a day-to-day basis is really enforcing clarity of thinking.”
description: Maths wizard Dan diBartolomeo says Australia’s super funds may be underestimating the risks associated with illiquid assets.
